body.name: Raid of No Return (Nathan Hale's Hazardous Tales #7): A World War II Tale of the Doolittle Raid
body.merchantInfo: Sold by Shakespeare Book House and Fulfilled by Amazon.
editorialReviews: Editorial Reviews From School Library Journal Gr 3–7—Presented in the author's instantly recognizable artistic and storytelling style, this new series installment centers on the Doolittle air raid over Japan during World War II. The book starts with a brief explanation of events pre—Pearl Harbor (and an even briefer, information-packed history of Japanese military history); soon after, the action begins with a literal bang. Hale describes the bombing of Pearl Harbor from Japanese and American points of view. In response, the U.S. military set up a supersecret counterattack organized by stunt pilot Jimmy Doolittle. Pilots and crew manning 16 planes trained to bomb targets over Japan. Their fate after the attack is harrowing and no detail is left out. While small, the panels are readable, and the graphic novel's small size makes it portable. Though works of history might not fly off the shelves, Hale's tendency to incorporate character commentary, infographics, and fun facts will draw readers. VERDICT Purchase for all libraries, and give this title to readers interested in action-packed graphic novels, especially patrons aging out of the "Magic Treehouse" books.—Morgan Brickey, Arlington Public Library, TX Review "Harrowing and no detail is left out . . . Hale’s tendency to incorporate character commentary, infographics, and fun facts will draw readers. Give this title to readers interested in action-packed graphic novels."―School Library Journal About the Author Nathan Hale is the #1 New York Times bestselling author and illustrator of the Nathan Hale’s Hazardous Tales series. He also wrote and illustrated the graphic novels One Trick Pony and Apocalypse Taco. Hale lives in Utah, and you can find him online. Read more

body.description: In author-illustrator Nathan Hale’s Raid of No Return, go behind the scenes of World War II’s top-secret Doolittle Raid with the New York Times bestselling Hazardous Tales graphic novel series!“These books are, quite simply, brilliant. . . . Thrilling, bloody, action-packed stories from American history.” —New York Times Presented in the author’s instantly recognizable artistic and storytelling style, this colorful, exciting book of history for kids starts with a brief explanation of the events leading up to World War II and then describes the bombing of Pearl Harbor from both the Japanese and American points of view. The American response was a super-secret counterattack organized by stunt pilot Jimmy Doolittle. Just four months after Pearl Harbor, American crews would launch sixteen B-25 bombers from the aircraft carrier USS Hornet to drop bombs on the Japanese capital Tokyo and then fly to safety in China. Everything about the mission was as dangerous as it was secret. B-25s were not designed to take off from an aircraft carrier. Japan had formidable air defenses. There was no way to plan for landing in China or returning safely to America. The Doolittle Raid, as it became known, went down in military history as one of the most creative and harrowing missions of World War II. The pilots and crews became American heroes.Nathan Hale’s Hazardous Tales! Read them all—if you dare!One Dead Spy: A Revolutionary War Tale (#1)Big Bad Ironclad!: A Civil War Tale (#2)Donner Dinner Party: A Pioneer Tale (#3)Treaties, Trenches, Mud, and Blood: A World War I Tale (#4)The Underground Abductor: An Abolitionist Tale about Harriet Tubman (#5)Alamo All-Stars: A Texas Tale (#6)Raid of No Return: A World War II Tale of the Doolittle Raid (#7)Lafayette!: A Revolutionary War Tale (#8)Major Impossible: A Grand Canyon Tale (#9)Blades of Freedom: A Tale of Haiti, Napoleon, and the Louisiana Purchase (#10)Cold War Correspondent: A Korean War Tale (#11)Above the Trenches: A WWI Flying Ace Tale (#12)

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2023
Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Nephew loves this series
reviews.reviewText: He's already finished reading it its graphic novel style type book but tells historical events

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great book for history fans
reviews.reviewText: It’s a great book and very accurate to history

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2017
reviews.reviewText: This is a good book, an interesting story based on real history. If you have read the book "Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo," this book gives an excellent visual reference. My teens devoured the book, reading it five times in four days.Some language may not be appropriate for young readers: damn and hellThe illustrations in the book do a great job with the American and Japanese fleets. One of my sons wanted more about the Japanese.Two details noted by another son were left out: the book omits Enterprise's role in providing air escorts for the Raiders, and the perfect timing required to launch the B-25s off the deck of the Hornet.Highly recommend this entire series. More books like this, please!One son asks for a book about the Navy Seal Medal of Honor winners in Viet Nam. Another wants one about "54-40 or Fight!" It would be great to have a book about the Pueblo Revolt of 1680.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2019
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Awesome book from an amazing series!!
reviews.reviewText: Picked this up for my 12 year old son, who absolutely ADORES the Nathan Hale books. This one did not disappoint!Seriously parents, if you have a reluctant reader who begrudgingly picks up books, you must check this series out!• Engaging and fun.• Historically accurate, therefore very educational!• Great illustrations.• Fresh and well-written.My son devours these books from cover to cover. I’ve even had to confiscate them when he has chosen to read “ just a little bit more” when he is supposed to be sleeping. In my opinion, that is demonstrative of a pretty awesome book!With all of the devices and technology at their fingertips, it’s great when they would rather opt for a book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2018
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Nicely Drawn and Informative
reviews.reviewText: I was not at all familiar with this WWII mission, so I learned a lot. I really enjoyed the blue palette, which was a nice calming balance for the war activity in addition to it just making sense for all the ocean involved, and felt having the larger panels helped. Sometimes this books pack too many panels on one page and it's a lot to take it. Love this series.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2018
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Good for avid and reluctant readers
reviews.reviewText: My 8yo son has read each of the NHHT books multiple times. He keeps one with him wherever he goes. They can have themes that may be shocking for some, but those opened good discussions for our family. For example, _The Underground Abductor_ exposes some atrocities of slavery that I wasn't aware of. Our kid asked questions, and we talked them out.If you have a kid who loves learning and humor and you can handle having discussions about hard stuff occasionally, then I highly recommend these books.We have loaned a couple to friends who don't love reading for pleasure, and they also LOVED these books.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Historically accurate & good story flow
reviews.reviewText: My 9 year old is addicted to Nathan Hale's books. He loves history and comic books, so Hale combines the best of both worlds. The artistry is good. The stories are historically accurate. The story format is easy to follow and packs a lot of information into an easy-to-read format. My mother is a reading specialist and I am a librarian and we both plan on using these in our respective areas of reading education.
My 9 year old son loved this book.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great gift for a boy who is interested in anything related to military, guns, tanks
reviews.reviewText: Birthday boy was very happy. He read the books repeatedly

reviews.reviewTitle: really great book for kids or adults
reviews.reviewText: This is a great book, my son enjoyed it immensely. Ordered more from same author. Hope they are as good as this one.

reviews.reviewTitle: they read this immediately and loved it!
reviews.reviewText: This was a Christmas present for my boys who have read all books in the Hazardous Tales series. As expected, they read this immediately and loved it!
